revision.text:
{{About|the phenomenon in general|nuclear EMP weapons|Nuclear electromagnetic pulse}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} An '''electromagnetic pulse''' ('''EMP'''), also sometimes called a transient electromagnetic disturbance, is a short burst of [[electromagnetic]] energy. Such a pulse's origination may be a natural occurrence or man-made and can occur as a [[electromagnetic field|radiated]], [[electric field|electric]], or [[magnetic field]] or a conducted [[electric current]], depending on the source. EMP interference is generally disruptive or damaging to electronic equipment, and at higher energy levels a powerful EMP event such as a lightning strike can damage physical objects such as buildings and aircraft structures. The management of EMP effects is an important branch of [[electromagnetic compatibility]] (EMC) engineering. Weapons have been developed to deliver the damaging effects of high-energy EMP. == General characteristics == An electromagnetic pulse is a short burst of electromagnetic energy. Its short duration means that it will be spread over a range of frequencies. Pulses are typically characterized by: * The type of energy (radiated, electric, magnetic or conducted). * The range or spectrum of frequencies present. * Pulse waveform: shape, duration and amplitude. The last two of these, the frequency spectrum and the pulse waveform, are interrelated via the [[Fourier transform]] and may be seen as two different ways of describing the same pulse. === Types of energy === {{Main|Electromagnetism}} EMP energy may be transferred in any of four forms: * [[Electric field]] * [[Magnetic field]] * [[Electromagnetic radiation]] * [[Electrical conduction]] Due to [[Maxwell's equations]], a pulse of any one form of electromagnetic energy will always be accompanied by the other forms, however in a typical pulse one form will dominate. In general, only radiation acts over long distances, with the others acting over short distances. There are a few exceptions, such as a [[solar flare|solar magnetic flare]]. === Frequency ranges === A pulse of electromagnetic energy typically comprises many frequencies from DC (zero Hz) to some upper limit depending on the source. The range defined as EMP, sometimes referred to as "DC to daylight", excludes the highest frequencies comprising the optical (infrared, visible, ultraviolet) and ionizing (X and gamma rays) ranges. Some types of EMP events can leave an optical trail, such as lightning and sparks, but these are side effects of the current flow through the air and are not part of the EMP itself. === Pulse waveforms === The waveform of a pulse describes how its instantaneous amplitude (field strength or current) changes over time. Real pulses tend to be quite complicated, so simplified models are often used. Such a model is typically described either in a diagram or as a mathematical equation. {| style="margin:0.5em auto 0.5em auto; text-align:center;" cellpadding=4 |- | [[File:rectangular pulse.svg|200px|alt=" "]]
Rectangular pulse | [[File:double exponential.svg|200px|alt=" "]]
Double exponential pulse | [[File:damped sinewave.svg|200px|alt=" "]]
Damped sinewave pulse |} Most electromagnetic pulses have a very sharp leading edge, building up quickly to their maximum level. The classic model is a double-exponential curve which climbs steeply, quickly reaches a peak and then decays more slowly. However, pulses from a controlled switching circuit often approximate the form of a rectangular or "square" pulse. EMP events usually induce a corresponding signal in the victim equipment, due to [[Electromagnetic compatibility#Coupling mechanisms|coupling]] between the source and victim. Coupling usually occurs most strongly over a relatively narrow frequency band, leading to a characteristic [[damped sine wave]] signal in the victim. Visually it is shown as a high frequency sine wave growing and decaying within the longer-lived envelope of the double-exponential curve. A damped sinewave typically has much lower energy and a narrower frequency spread than the original pulse, due to the transfer characteristic of the coupling mode. In practice, EMP test equipment often injects these damped sinewaves directly rather than attempting to recreate the high-energy threat pulses. In a pulse train, such as from a digital clock circuit, the waveform is repeated at regular intervals. A single complete pulse cycle is sufficient to characterise such a regular, repetitive train. == Types == An EMP arises where the source emits a short-duration pulse of energy. The energy is usually broadband by nature, although it often excites a relatively narrow-band ''[[damped sine wave]]'' response in the victim. Some types are generated as repetitive and regular ''[[Voltage spike|pulse]] trains''. Different types of EMP arise from natural, man-made, and weapons effects. Types of natural EMP event include: * [[Lightning]] electromagnetic pulse (LEMP). The discharge is typically an initial huge current flow, at least mega-amps, followed by a train of pulses of decreasing energy. * [[Electrostatic discharge]] (ESD), as a result of two charged objects coming into close proximity or even contact. * Meteoric EMP. The discharge of electromagnetic energy resulting from either the impact of a [[meteoroid]] with a spacecraft or the explosive breakup of a meteoroid passing through the Earth's atmosphere.{{cite journal |first=S. |last=Close |first2=P. |last2=Colestock |first3=L. |last3=Cox |first4=M. |last4=Kelley |first5=N. |last5=Lee |title=Electromagnetic pulses generated by meteoroid impacts on spacecraft |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=115 |page=A12328 |year=2010 |doi=10.1029/2010JA015921 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2010JA015921/pdf |format=PDF|bibcode=2010JGRA..11512328C }}{{cite web |first=Charles |last=Chandler |title=Meteoric Airbursts: General Principles |publisher=QDL blog |url=http://qdl.scs-inc.us/2ndParty/Pages/7793.html |accessdate=30 December 2014}} * [[Coronal mass ejection]] (CME). A burst of [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] and accompanying magnetic field, ejected from the solar corona and released into the [[solar wind]]. Sometimes referred to as a Solar EMP.{{cite web|url=http://www.empactamerica.org/solar_emp.php |title=EMPACT America, Inc. - Solar EMP |publisher=[[Web.archive.org]] |date=2011-07-26 |accessdate=2015-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726030320/http://www.empactamerica.org/solar_emp.php |archivedate=26 July 2011 }} Types of (civil) man-made EMP event include: * Switching action of electrical circuitry, whether isolated or repetitive (as a pulse train). * [[Electric motor]]s can create a train of pulses as the internal electrical contacts make and break connections as the armature rotates. * Gasoline engine ignition systems can create a train of pulses as the spark plugs are energized or fired. * Continual switching actions of digital electronic circuitry. * [[Electric power transmission|Power line]] surges. These can be up to several kilovolts, enough to damage electronic equipment that is insufficiently protected. Types of military EMP include: * [[Nuclear electromagnetic pulse]] (NEMP), as a result of a nuclear explosion. A variant of this is the high altitude nuclear EMP (HEMP), which produces a secondary pulse due to particle interactions with the [[Earth's atmosphere]] and magnetic field. * Non-nuclear electromagnetic pulse (NNEMP) weapons. === Lightning === {{Main|Lightning}} Lightning is unusual in that it typically has a preliminary "leader" discharge of low energy building up to the main pulse, which in turn may be followed at intervals by several smaller bursts.{{cite journal |url=http://www.lightning.ece.ufl.edu/PDF/Howard%20et%20al%20%5B2011%5Da.pdf |format=PDF |title=Measured close lightning leader step electric field derivative waveforms |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=116 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2010JD015249|bibcode=2011JGRD..116.8201H | last1 = Howard | first1 = J. | last2 = Uman | first2 = M. A. | last3 = Biagi | first3 = C. | last4 = Hill | first4 = D. | last5 = Rakov | first5 = V. A. | last6 = Jordan | first6 = D. M.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.weighing-systems.com/TechnologyCentre/Lightning1.pdf |format=PDF |title=A Basic Primer in Lightning Effects and Protection |publisher=weighing-systems.com |accessdate=8 September 2015}} === Electrostatic discharge (ESD) === {{Main|Electrostatic discharge}} ESD events are characterised by high voltages of many kV but small currents and sometimes cause visible sparks. ESD is treated as a small, localised phenomenon, although technically a lightning flash is a very large ESD event. ESD can also be man-made, as in the shock received from a [[Van de Graaff generator]]. An ESD event can damage electronic circuitry by injecting a high-voltage pulse, besides giving people an unpleasant shock. Such an ESD event can also create sparks, which may in turn ignite fires or fuel-vapour explosions. For this reason, before refuelling an aircraft or exposing any fuel vapour to the air, the fuel nozzle is first connected to the aircraft to safely discharge any static. === Switching pulses === The switching action of an electrical circuit creates a sharp change in the flow of electricity. This sharp change is a form of EMP. Simple electrical sources include inductive loads such as relays, solenoids, and the brush contacts in electric motors. Typically these send a pulse down any electrical connections present, as well as radiating a pulse of energy. The amplitude is usually small and the signal may be treated as "noise" or "interference". The switching off or "opening" of a circuit causes an abrupt change in the current flowing. This can in turn cause a large pulse in the electric field across the open contacts, causing arcing and damage. It is often necessary to incorporate design features to limit such effects. Electronic devices such as vacuum tubes or valves, transistors and diodes can also switch on and off very quickly, causing similar issues. One-off pulses may be caused by solid-state switches and other devices used only occasionally. However, the many millions of transistors in a modern computer may switch repeatedly at frequencies above 1 GHz, causing interference which appears to be continuous. === Nuclear electromagnetic pulse (NEMP) === {{Main|Nuclear electromagnetic pulse}} A nuclear electromagnetic pulse is the abrupt pulse of electromagnetic radiation resulting from a [[nuclear explosion]]. The resulting rapidly changing [[electric fields]] and magnetic fields may couple with electrical/electronic systems to produce damaging current and [[voltage spike|voltage surges]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21728664-north-korea-has-given-electricity-industry-jolt-fear-americas-utilities-prepare|title=America’s utilities prepare for a nuclear threat to the grid|work=[[The Economist]]|access-date=2017-09-21|language=en}} The intense [[gamma radiation]] emitted can also ionize the surrounding air, creating a secondary EMP as the atoms of air first lose their electrons and then regain them. [[Nuclear EMP|NEMP]] weapons are designed to maximize such EMP effects as the primary damage mechanism, and some are capable of destroying susceptible electronic equipment over a wide area. A high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) weapon is a NEMP warhead designed to be detonated far above the Earth's surface. The explosion releases a blast of gamma rays into the mid-[[stratosphere]], which ionizes as a secondary effect and the resultant energetic free electrons interact with the Earth's magnetic field to produce a much stronger EMP than is normally produced in the denser air at lower altitudes. === Non-nuclear electromagnetic pulse (NNEMP) === Non-nuclear electromagnetic pulse (NNEMP) is a weapon-generated electromagnetic pulse without use of nuclear technology. Devices that can achieve this objective include a large low-inductance [[capacitor]] bank discharged into a single-loop antenna, a microwave generator, and an [[explosively pumped flux compression generator]]. To achieve the frequency characteristics of the pulse needed for optimal [[coupling (electronics)|coupling]] into the target, [[Electromagnetic wave|wave]]-shaping circuits or microwave generators are added between the pulse source and the [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]]. [[Vircator]]s are vacuum tubes that are particularly suitable for microwave conversion of high-energy pulses.{{cite journal |url=http://www.dtic.mil/docs/citations/ADA332511 |title=The Electromagnetic Bomb - A Weapon of Electrical Mass Destruction |date=October 1996 |last=Kopp |first=Carlo |author-link=Carlo Kopp |journal=USAF CADRE Air Chronicles |publisher=[[U.S. Air Force]] |id=DTIC:ADA332511 |accessdate=12 January 2012}} NNEMP generators can be carried as a payload of bombs, [[cruise missile]]s (such as the [[Counter-electronics High Power Microwave Advanced Missile Project|CHAMP]] missile) and [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]], with diminished mechanical, thermal and ionizing radiation effects, but without the consequences of deploying nuclear weapons. The range of NNEMP weapons is much less than nuclear EMP. Nearly all NNEMP devices used as weapons require chemical explosives as their initial energy source, producing only 10−6 (one millionth) the energy of nuclear explosives of similar weight.{{sfn|Glasstone|Dolan|1977|loc=Chapter 1}} The electromagnetic pulse from NNEMP weapons must come from within the weapon, while nuclear weapons generate EMP as a secondary effect.{{sfn|Glasstone|Dolan|1977|loc=Chapter 11, section 11.73}} These facts limit the range of NNEMP weapons, but allow finer target discrimination. The effect of small e-bombs has proven to be sufficient for certain terrorist or military operations.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Examples of such operations include the destruction of electronic control systems critical to the operation of many ground vehicles and aircraft.{{cite news |last=Marks |first=Paul |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20227026.200-aircraft-could-be-brought-down-by-diy-ebombs.html |title=Aircraft could be brought down by DIY 'E-bombs' |newspaper=[[New Scientist]] |date=1 April 2009 |pages=16–17}}{{additional citation needed|reason=cited article is mostly speculation, not fact|date=July 2016}} The concept of the explosively pumped flux compression generator for generating a non-nuclear electromagnetic pulse was conceived as early as 1951 by [[Andrei Sakharov]] in the Soviet Union,{{cite journal |first=Stephen |last=Younger |title=Scientific Collaborations Between Los Alamos and Arzamas-16 Using Explosive-Driven Flux Compression Generators |journal=[[Los Alamos Science]] |issue=24 |pages=48–71 |year=1996 |url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/othergov/doe/lanl/pubs/00326620.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-10-24 |displayauthors=etal }} but nations kept work on non-nuclear EMP classified until similar ideas emerged in other nations. === Electromagnetic forming === {{Main|Electromagnetic forming}} The large forces generated by electromagnetic pulses can be used to shape or form objects as part of their manufacturing process. == Effects == Minor EMP events, and especially pulse trains, cause low levels of electrical noise or interference which can affect the operation of susceptible devices. For example, a common problem in the mid-twentieth century was interference emitted by the ignition systems of gasoline engines, which caused radio sets to crackle and TV sets to show stripes on the screen. Laws were introduced to make vehicle manufacturers fit interference suppressors. At a high voltage level an EMP can induce a spark, for example from an electrostatic discharge when fuelling a gasoline-engined vehicle. Such sparks have been known to cause fuel-air explosions and precautions must be taken to prevent them."Fundamentals of Electrostatic Discharge", Compliance Magazine, 1 May 2015. Retrieved 25 June 2015. A large and energetic EMP can induce high currents and voltages in the victim unit, temporarily disrupting its function or even permanently damaging it. A powerful EMP can also directly affect magnetic materials and corrupt the data stored on media such as [[magnetic tape]] and computer [[hard drive]]s. Hard drives are usually shielded by heavy metal casings. Some [[IT asset management|IT asset disposition]] service providers and computer recyclers use a controlled EMP to wipe such magnetic media.{{Cite web|url=https://www.newtechrecycling.com/shredding/hard_drives/how_to_permanently_delete_data.html#data_wipe|title=EMP Data Wipe|author=|date=|publisher=Newtech Recycling|website=www.newtechrecycling.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-12}} A very large EMP event such as a lightning strike is also capable of damaging objects such as trees, buildings and aircraft directly, either through heating effects or the disruptive effects of the very large magnetic field generated by the current. An indirect effect can be electrical fires caused by heating. Most engineered structures and systems require some form of protection against lightning to be designed in. The damaging effects of high-energy EMP have led to the introduction of EMP weapons, from tactical missiles with a small radius of effect to nuclear bombs tailored for maximum EMP effect over a wide area. == Control == [[File:E-4 advanced airborne command post EMP sim.jpg|thumb|EMP simulator HAGII-C testing a [[Boeing E-4]] aircraft.]] [[File:USS Estocin FFG-15 moored near EMPRESS I.jpg|thumb|EMPRESS I (antennas along shoreline) with {{USS|Estocin|FFG-15}} moored in the foreground for testing.]] {{main|Electromagnetic compatibility}} Like any [[electromagnetic interference]], the threat from EMP is subject to control measures. This is true whether the threat is natural or man-made. Therefore, most control measures focus on the susceptibility of equipment to EMP effects, and [[radiation hardening|hardening]] or protecting it from harm. Man-made sources, other than weapons, are also subject to control measures in order to limit the amount of pulse energy emitted. The discipline of ensuring correct equipment operation in the presence of EMP and other RF threats is known as electromagnetic compatibility (EMC). === Test simulation === To test the effects of EMP on engineered systems and equipment, an EMP simulator may be used. ==== Induced pulse simulation ==== Induced pulses are of much lower energy than threat pulses and so are more practicable to create, but they are less predictable. A common test technique is to use a [[current clamp]] in reverse, to inject a range of damped sine wave signals into a cable connected to the equipment under test. The damped sine wave generator is able to reproduce the range of induced signals likely to occur. ==== Threat pulse simulation ==== Sometimes the threat pulse itself is simulated in a repeatable way. The pulse may be reproduced at low energy in order to characterise the victim's response prior to damped sinewave injection, or at high energy to recreate the actual threat conditions. A small-scale [[Electrostatic discharge#Simulation and testing for electronic devices|ESD simulator]] may be hand-held. Bench- or room-sized simulators come in a range of designs, depending on the type and level of threat to be generated. At the top end of the scale, large outdoor test facilities incorporating high-energy EMP simulators have been built by several countries. The largest facilities are able to test whole vehicles including ships and aircraft for their susceptibility to EMP. Nearly all of these large EMP simulators used a specialized version of a [[Marx generator]].{{cite journal |last=Baum |first=Carl E. |journal=IEEE Transactions on Electromagnetic Compatibility |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=211–8 |date=May 2007 |url=http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/notes/History/BaumReminiscences.pdf |format=PDF |title=Reminiscences of High-Power Electromagnetics |doi=10.1109/temc.2007.897147}}{{cite journal |last=Baum |first=Carl E. |journal=Proceedings of the IEEE |volume=80 |issue=6 |pages=789–817 |date=June 1992 |url=http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/notes/SDAN/0032.pdf |format=PDF |title=From the Electromagnetic Pulse to High-Power Electromagnetics|bibcode=1992IEEEP..80..789B |doi=10.1109/5.149443}} Examples include the huge wooden-structured [[ATLAS-I]] simulator (also known as TRESTLE) at [[Sandia National Labs]], New Mexico, which was at one time the world's largest EMP simulator.{{cite web |last=Reuben |first=Charles |url=http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/notes/trestle.html |title=The Atlas-I Trestle at Kirtland Air Force Base |publisher=The University of New Mexico}} Papers on this and other large EMP simulators used by the United States during the latter part of the [[Cold War]], along with more general information about electromagnetic pulses, are now in the care of the SUMMA Foundation, which is hosted at the University of New Mexico.[http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/ SUMMA Foundation web site]{{cite web|url=http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/index.htm |title=SUMMA Foundation - Carl Baum, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of New Mexico |publisher=Ece.unm.edu |date=2013-01-17 |accessdate=2013-06-18}} The US Navy also has a large facility called the Electro Magnetic Pulse Radiation Environmental Simulator for Ships I (EMPRESS I). ==Safety== High-level EMP signals can pose a threat to human safety. In such circumstances, direct contact with a live electrical conductor should be avoided. Where this occurs, such as when touching a [[Van de Graaf generator]] or other highly-charged object, care must be taken to release the object and then discharge the body through a high resistance, in order to avoid the risk of a harmful shock pulse when stepping away. Very high electric field strengths can cause breakdown of the air and a potentially lethal arc current similar to lightning to flow, however electric field strengths of up to 200 kV/m (Kilovolts per metre) are regarded as safe.[https://fas.org/irp/doddir/dod/i6055_11.pdf Protecting Personnel from Electromagnetic Fields], US Department of Defence Instruction No. 6055.11, 19 August 2009. Magnetic pulses are generally safe, although extremely high pulse levels can affect brain activity, as in [[transcranial magnetic stimulation]]. == In popular culture == {{Main|Electromagnetic pulse in fiction and popular culture}} The popular media often depict EMP effects incorrectly, causing misunderstandings among the public and even professionals. Official efforts have been made in the US to disprove these misconceptions.Report Meta-R-320: "[http://www.ferc.gov/industries/electric/indus-act/reliability/cybersecurity/ferc_meta-r-320.pdf The Early-Time (E1) High-Altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) and Its Impact on the U.S. Power Grid]" January 2010. Written by Metatech Corporation for Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Appendix: E1 HEMP Myths2009 Telly Award Winners, (Manitou Motion Picture Company, Ltd.) [http://www.tellyawards.com/winners/list/?l=M&pageNum_winners=2&totalRows_winners=453&event=10&category=] The U.S. Space Command video is not available to the general public. == See also == {{Portal|Electromagnetism}} {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Directed-energy weapon]] * [[Electromagnetic environment]] * [[Electronic warfare]] * [[Faraday's law of induction]] * [[Geomagnetic storm]] * [[Pulsed power]] * [[Transient (oscillation)]] * [[Ultrashort pulse]] }} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == *{{cite book |first1=Samuel |last1=Glasstone|authorlink1=Samuel Glasstone |first2=Philip J. |last2=Dolan |authorlink2=Philip J. Dolan|year=1977|url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/etexts/www/effects/ |title=The Effects of Nuclear Weapons |publisher=United States Department of Defense and the Energy Research and Development Administration|ref=harv}} == External links == * [http://www.ece.unm.edu/summa/notes/trestle_movie.html TRESTLE: Landmark of the Cold War (Documentary Movie)], a short documentary on the SUMMA Foundation website. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Electromagnetic Pulse}} [[Category:Electromagnetic radiation]] [[Category:Energy weapons]] [[Category:Nuclear weapons]] [[Category:Electromagnetic compatibility]] [[Category:Electronic warfare]] [[Category:Pulsed power]]

{{Infobox protected area | name = Elk Neck State Park | iucn_category = III | iucn_ref = <ref name="IUCN1">{{cite web|title=Elk Neck State Park|url=https://www.protectedplanet.net/elk-neck-state-park|website=Protected Planet|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> <!-- images --> | photo = Turkey Point Lighthouse.jpg | photo_caption = [[Turkey Point Light]] <!-- map --> | map = USA Maryland | map_image = | map_size = 280 | map_caption = Location in Maryland | relief = 1 <!-- location --> | location = [[Cecil County, Maryland|Cecil]], Maryland, United States | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|39|29|04|N|75|58|59|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <ref name=gnis/> <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 2191 | area_ref = <ref name=acreagereport/> | elevation = {{convert|118|ft|m|abbr=on}}<ref name=gnis>{{cite gnis|588922|Elk Neck State Park}}</ref> | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 1936 | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = [[Maryland Department of Natural Resources]] | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = [http://dnr.maryland.gov/publiclands/Pages/central/elkneck.aspx Elk Neck State Park] | embedded = }}
'''Elk Neck State Park''' is a public recreation area located between [[Chesapeake Bay]] and the [[Elk River (Maryland)|Elk River]] near the southern tip of the [[Elk Neck Peninsula]] in [[Cecil County, Maryland|Cecil County]], [[Maryland]]. The [[state park]] is home to the historic [[Turkey Point Light]] and offers land-based and water-based recreation.<ref name=mdnr/> The park is located on [[Maryland Route 272|MD 272]], eight miles (13 km) south of the town of [[North East, Maryland|North East]], and {{convert|13|mi}} south of exit 100 on [[Interstate 95 in Maryland|I-95]]. It is operated by the [[Maryland Department of Natural Resources]].
==History== The park had its genesis when, in 1936, naturalist Dr. William Abbott bequeathed his holdings along the Elk River to the state for use as a state park. Although he originally intended the land to be a gift to the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]], a meeting with State Forester [[Maryland Forest Service|Fred W. Besley]] in 1935 persuaded Abbott to change the terms of his will. Following the state's purchase of additional acreage, the [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] created park improvements from 1937 to 1941.<ref name=cecilhistory/>
==Activities and amenities== ;Turkey Point Lighthouse Dating from 1833, the [[Turkey Point Light]]house sits on a {{convert|100|ft|sing=on}} bluff overlooking the Upper Chesapeake Bay. The {{convert|35|ft|sing=on}} tower is a "private aid to navigation" maintained by a non-profit organization, Turkey Point Light Station, Inc., which offers weekend tours seasonally.<ref name=tpls/> ;Campgrounds The park offers more than 250 campsites, rustic cabins, camper cabins, and youth group sites.<ref name=camping/> ;Trails The park has {{convert|12|mi}} of trails for hiking and biking.<ref name=trailstext/> {| class="wikitable" style="width:50%" |- ! Trail Name ! Length ! Difficulty |- | White Banks Trail | {{convert|3|mi|km|1}} | Difficult |- | Mauldin Mountain Loop | {{convert|1.5|mi|km|1}} | Difficult |- | Pond Loop | {{convert|1|mi|km|1}} | Moderate |- | Farm Road Trail | {{convert|1|mi|km|1}} | Moderate |- | Beaver Marsh Loop | {{convert|4|mi|km|1}} | Difficult |- | Lighthouse Trail | {{convert|2|mi|km|1}} | Easy |- | Ravines Loop | {{convert|.75|mi|km|1}} | Moderate |}
;Water recreation The park offers a swimming beach, fishing, and crabbing, plus a boat launch and launch area for canoeing and kayaking.<ref name=beach/><ref name=launch/>
==Ecology== The park is part of the [[Northeastern coastal forests]] [[ecoregion]], with a landscape characterized by deep forests, bluffs, beaches, and marshlands.<ref name="terrestrial"/>
==In popular culture== The park was used as a filming location for the 1997 Clint Eastwood movie ''[[Absolute Power (film)|Absolute Power]]''<ref name=imdb/><ref name=tourist/> and as the setting of an episode of the television series ''[[Hannibal (TV series)|Hannibal]]''.{{citationneeded|date=October 2016}}
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=mdnr>{{cite web |url=http://dnr.maryland.gov/publiclands/Pages/central/elkneck.aspx |title=Elk Neck State Park |publisher=Maryland Department of Natural Resources |accessdate=December 10, 2013}}</ref>

}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= Hyacinthe de Bougainville |birth_date=26 December 1781 |death_date= {{Death date and age|df=yes|1846|10|18|1781|12|26}} |birth_place= [[Brest, France]] |death_place= Paris, France |image= Hyacinthe de Bougainville.jpg |caption=Hyacinthe de Bougainville |nickname= |allegiance= [[File:Flag of France.svg|18px]] France |branch=[[French Navy]] |serviceyears= |rank=[[Rear Admiral]] |commands= |laterwork= }} '''Hyacinthe Yves Philippe Potentien, baron de Bougainville''' (26 December 1781 – 18 October 1846) was a [[History of the French Navy|French naval officer]]. He was the son of [[Louis-Antoine de Bougainville]].Randier, p.292 He became [[Rear-Admiral]] on 1 May 1838. ==Career== As a young second-class midshipman of eighteen Hyacinthe de Bougainville participated in the 1800-02 [[Baudin expedition of 1800 to 1802|Baudin expedition]] to Australia.Horner, F. The French Reconnaissance: Baudin in Australia 1801—1803, Melbourne University Press, Melbourne, 1987 {{ISBN|0-522-84339-5}}. Hyacinthe de Bougainville [[circumnavigator|sailed around the world]] from 1824 to 1826 onboard ''Thétis'' and ''Espérance'', sent by the [[Minister of the Navy and the Colonies]], the [[Aimé, duc de Clermont-Tonnerre|duc de Clermont-Tonnerre]].Colin L. Dyer, ''The French Explorers and the Aboriginal Australians 1772-1839'' p.12 [https://books.google.com/books?id=gnu_RmVvypMC&pg=PA11&dq=%22Hyacinthe+de+Bougainville%22&sig=ACfU3U3J-ZBbxXm2xcWkocbBH7ng9KRKXw#PPA12,M1] [[File:La Thetis 1813 model.jpg|thumb|left|Frigate [[French frigate Thétis (1819)|''Thétis'']], 1813 model. [[Musée National de la Marine (Rochefort)]].]] On 12 January 1825, Hyacinthe de Bougainville led an embassy to [[Vietnam]] with Captain [[Courson de la Ville-Hélio]], arriving in [[Da Nang]], with the warships ''Thétis'' and ''Espérance''.Oscar Chapuis, ''A History of Vietnam: From Hong Bang to Tu Duc'' p. 190. Although they had numerous presents for the Emperor, and a 28 January 1824 letter from [[Louis XVIII]], the ambassadors could not obtain an audience from [[Minh Mạng]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=9RorGHF0fGIC&pg=PA4&dq=Bougainville+Danang&sig=ACfU3U0DB5y6exGyUoY2foqpOWxsHHy47A Oscar Chapuis, ''The Last Emperors of Vietnam'' p.4] Hyacinthe de Bougainville infiltrated Father Regéreau from the ''Thétis'' when it was anchored in Da Nang, triggering edicts of persecution against Christianity by Minh Mạng.[https://books.google.com/books?id=hWjx-6WM6PMC&pg=PA25&dq=Bougainville+Danang&sig=ACfU3U3Ta5vUQoDiNHUBwvFtl-5r-yM1Eg#PPA27,M1 ''The Vietnamese Response to French Intervention, 1862-1874'' p.27] Bougainville visited [[New South Wales]] in 1825. That same year, he visited [[Port Jackson]]Colin L. Dyer, ''The French Explorers and the Aboriginal Australians 1772-1839: 1772-1839'' p. 11 [https://books.google.com/books?id=gnu_RmVvypMC&pg=PA11&dq=Hyacinthe+de+Bougainville&sig=ACfU3U3J-ZBbxXm2xcWkocbBH7ng9KRKXw#PPA12,M1] and [[Sydney]] where he set up a monument to [[Jean-François de Galaup, comte de La Pérouse|La Pérouse]] and erected a grave for [[Louis Receveur|le Receveur]] in [[Botany Bay]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2184418 |title=FURTHER DOCUMENTARY INTELLIGENCE, RECEIVED WITHIN THE LAST WEEK. |newspaper=[[Sydney Gazette|The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser]] |volume=XXIII |issue=1138 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=8 September 1825 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}
{{Citation | author1=Oxley, John | title=Plan of the two allotments of ground, on the North Shore of Botany Bay, released by His Excellency Sir Thomas Brisbane K.C.B., etc.etc.etc. to Monr. Le Baron de Bougainville commanding His Most Christian Majesty's Ship Thesis, for the purpose of erecting monuments to the memory of Count De La Perouse & Father Le Receveur | publication-date=1825 | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/35785016}}{{Cite book| url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8668395| author=Maria Nugent| date=2005| title=Botany Bay: Where Histories Meet| page=101| isbn=978-1-74114-575-5}} He became acquainted with the leading colonial Sydney figures of the day including [[John Piper (military officer)|John Piper]], [[Samuel Marsden]], [[John Macarthur (wool pioneer)|John Macarthur]], and [[John Blaxland (explorer)|John Blaxland]]. The daughter of the latter, Harriot Blaxland Ritchie, became romantically involved with Bougainville. ==Works== ''Journal de la Navigation Autour Du Globe de la Frégate Thétis et de la Corvette L'Espérance'' (Paris : Arthus Bertrand) 1837. ==See also== *[[France-Vietnam relations]] * [[European and American voyages of scientific exploration]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Randier, Jean 2006 ''La Royale'' Editions Babouji {{ISBN|2-35261-022-2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bougainville, Hyacinthe De}} [[Category:French Navy admirals]] [[Category:1781 births]] [[Category:1846 deaths]] [[Category:People from Brest, France]] [[Category:Circumnavigators of the globe]]

[[File:Lake Stratification (11).svg|thumb|Lakes are stratified into three separate sections:
Ⅰ. The ''[[Epilimnion]]''
Ⅱ. The ''[[Thermocline|Metalimnion]]''
Ⅲ. The Hypolimnion
The scales are used to associate each section of the stratification to their corresponding depths and temperatures. The arrow is used to show the movement of wind over the surface of the water which initiates the turnover in the epilimnion and the hypolimnion.]] {{lake stratification topics}} The '''hypolimnion''' or '''under lake''' is the dense, bottom layer of water in a thermally-[[Lake stratification|stratified lake]]. It is the layer that lies below the [[thermocline]]. Typically the hypolimnion is the coldest layer of a lake in summer, and the warmest layer during winter. Being at depth, it is isolated from surface [[wind-mixing]] during summer, and usually receives insufficient irradiance (light) for [[photosynthesis]] to occur. In deep, [[Temperate zone|temperate]] lakes, the bottom-most waters of the hypolimnion are typically close to 4 °C throughout the year. The hypolimnion may be much warmer in lakes at warmer latitudes. ==See also== *[[Epilimnion]] *[[Metalimnion]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{unsourced|date=August 2010}} ==External links== *[http://wow.nrri.umn.edu/wow/teacher/thermal/teaching.html Water on the Web] {{geo-term-stub}} [[Category:Limnology]] [[Category:Aquatic ecology]]

This is a '''list of National Park System areas in New York'''. New York has 24 areas included in the United States' [[National Park Service]] (NPS) system. The NPS administers the nation's flagship national parks, none of which are in New York, and additional natural or historic parks and other sites. ==Current NPS areas== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%" ! width="1%" | ! width="18%" |'''Landmark name'''
! class="unsortable" width="13%" |'''Image''' !date width="3%" |'''Date established'''{{Cite document | last = National Park Service | first = | author-link = National Park Service |date=June 27, 2005 | title = National Park System Areas Listed in Chronological Order of Date Authorized Under DOI | publisher = National Park Service, Department of the Interior | url=http://www.nps.gov/applications/budget2/documents/chronop.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-08-27 | postscript = }}.{{cite web | last = National Park Service | first = | authorlink = National Park Service | year=2008 | title = Antiquities Act monuments list | publisher = National Park Service | url=http://www.nps.gov/history/archeology/sites/antiquities/MonumentsList.htm | accessdate = 2008-08-27 }} ! width="9%" |'''Location''' ! width="8%" |'''County''' ! class="unsortable" width="48%" |'''Description''' |-- ! |* | [[Gateway National Recreation Area]] | [[File:GRNAlandscapes.JPG|100px|Jamaica Bay Coastal Landscapes at Gateway]] | {{dts|1972|10|27}} | | | |-- ! |* | [[Fire Island National Seashore]] | [[File:Fire Island Lighthouse-New York State-NPS.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1964|09|11}} | | | |-- ! |* | [[Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River]] | | | | | |-- ! |* | [[North Country National Scenic Trail]] | | | | | |-- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMON|*}} | [[Castle Clinton National Monument]] | [[Image:Habs castle clinton.jpg|100px|Castle Clinton in Battery Park (HABS)]] | {{dts|1946|8|12}} | [[New York, New York|New York]] | [[New York County|New York]] | Circular sandstone [[fort]] in [[Battery Park (New York)|Battery Park]] at the southern tip of [[Manhattan]], New York City |-- ! {{NMON color}} |* | [[Statue of Liberty National Monument]] | [[Image:Liberty 2005 3.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1924|10|15}} | [[Liberty Island]] | [[New York County|New York]] | Monument presented to the United States by the people of France in 1886 |-- ! {{NRHPlegend|NHP|*}} | [[Saratoga National Historical Park]] | | {{dts|1938|6|1}} | [[Stillwater, New York|Stillwater]], [[Schuylerville, New York|Schuylerville]] and [[Victory, Saratoga County, New York|Victory]] | [[Saratoga County, New York|Saratoga]] | Site of the 1777 [[Battle of Saratoga]], the first significant American military victory of the [[American Revolutionary War]] |-- ! {{NHP color}} |* | [[Women's Rights National Historical Park]] | [[Image:WesleyanChapel.JPG|100px|Remains of the Wesleyan Chapel.]] | {{dts|1980|12|8}} | [[Seneca Falls (village), New York|Seneca Falls]] and [[Waterloo, New York|Waterloo]] | [[Seneca County, New York|Seneca]] | Established in 1980 in [[Seneca Falls (village), New York|Seneca Falls]] and nearby [[Waterloo, New York|Waterloo]], New York; includes the [[Methodism|Wesleyan]] Chapel, site of the [[Seneca Falls Convention]], which was the first [[women's rights]] convention, and the [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton House (New York)|Elizabeth Cady Stanton House]] |-- ! {{NRHPlegend|NHS|*}} | [[Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site]] | [[Image:EleanorRooseveltNationalHistoricSite StoneCottage 2007 02.jpg|100px|Stone Cottage]] | {{dts|1977|5|27}} | [[Hyde Park, New York|Hyde Park]] | [[Dutchess County, New York|Dutchess]] | [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] developed property; place that she could develop some of her ideas for work with winter jobs for rural workers and women; includes a large two-story stuccoed building that housed [[Val-Kill Industries]]; would become Eleanor's home after Franklin's death |-- ! {{NHS color}} |* | [[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site]] | [[File:Springwood FDR home NY1.jpg|100px|Front elevation of house]] | {{dts|1944|1|15}} | [[Hyde Park, New York|Hyde Park]] | [[Dutchess County, New York|Dutchess]] | Birthplace, lifelong home, and burial place of the 32nd President of the United States, [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] |-- ! {{NHS color}} |* | [[Sagamore Hill National Historic Site]] | [[Image:Sagamore Hill.jpg|100px|Sagamore Hill]] | {{dts|1962|7|25}} | [[Cove Neck, New York|Cove Neck]] | [[Nassau County, New York|Nassau]] | Home of the 26th [[President of the United States]] [[Theodore Roosevelt]] from 1886 until his death in 1919 |-- ! {{NHS color}} |* | [[Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site]] | [[Image:TR birthplace.JPG|100px|The front and entrance of the house.]] | {{dts|1962|7|25}} | [[New York, New York|New York]] | [[New York County, New York|New York]] | [[Theodore Roosevelt]] born on this site on October 27, 1858 |-- ! {{NHS color}} |* | [[Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site]] | [[Image:Ansley-wilcox-house.jpg|100px|Ansley Wilcox House, 1965]] | {{dts|1966|11|2}} | [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] | [[Erie County, New York|Erie]] | Site of [[Theodore Roosevelt]]'s oath of office as President of the United States on September 14, 1901 |-- ! {{NHS color}} |* | [[Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site]] | [[File:Hyde Park Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site.jpg|100px|The severe classicism, perfect balance, and heavy ornamentation of Hyde Park, designed for Frederick Vanderbilt by McKim, Mead & White, is a perfect example of Beaux-Arts architecture.]] | {{dts|1940|12|18}} | [[Hyde Park, New York|Hyde Park]] | [[Dutchess County, New York|Dutchess]] | Includes pleasure grounds with views of the [[Hudson River]] and [[Catskill Mountains]], formal gardens, natural woodlands, and numerous support structures as well as a 54-room mansion; completed in 1898; perfect example of the [[Beaux-Arts architecture]] style |-- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMEM|*}} | [[Federal Hall National Memorial]] | [[File:Federal Hall NYC1.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1939|5|26}} | [[New York, New York|New York]] | [[New York County, New York|New York]] | First capitol of the United States of America; site of [[George Washington]]'s first inauguration in 1789; place where the [[United States Bill of Rights]] passed; original building was demolished in the nineteenth century; replaced by the current structure, that served as the first United States [[Custom House|Customs House]] |-- ! {{NMEM color}}|* | [[General Grant National Memorial]] | [[Image:USA grants tomb.jpg|100px|Grant's tomb 2004]] | {{dts|1897|4|27}} | [[New York, New York|New York]] | [[New York County, New York|New York]] | [[Mausoleum]] containing the bodies of [[Ulysses S. Grant]] (1822–1885), an [[American Civil War]] General and the 18th [[President of the United States]], and his wife, [[Julia Grant|Julia Dent Grant]] (1826–1902) |-- ! {{NRHPlegend|NHS|*}} |[[Thomas Cole House]]

''Thomas Cole National Historic Site'' |[[Image:Thomas-cole-house.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1965|6|23}} |[[Catskill (town), New York|Catskill]] {{coord|42.226372|-73.862007|name=Thomas Cole House Site|type:landmark}} |{{RHPcounty|Greene}} |Home and studio of painter [[Thomas Cole]], founder of the [[Hudson River School]] of American painting |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMON|*}} |[[Fort Stanwix]]

''Fort Stanwix National Monument'' |[[Image:Fost areal image007.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1962|11|23}} |[[Rome, New York|Rome]] {{coord|43.218611|-75.458889|name=Fort Stanwix|type:landmark}} |{{RHPcounty|Oneida}} |Modern reconstruction of colonial fort on original site |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NHS|*}} |[[Martin Van Buren National Historic Site|Lindenwald]]

''Martin Van Buren National Historic Site'' |[[Image:Lindenwald2006.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1961|7|4}} |[[Kinderhook, New York|Kinderhook]] {{coord|42.369706|-73.704206|name=Lindenwald|type:landmark}} |{{RHPcounty|Columbia}} |Home of U.S. President [[Martin Van Buren]]; designed in part by [[Richard Upjohn]] |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NHS|*}} |[[Kate Mullany House]] |[[Image:Kate Mullany House oblique view.jpg|100px]] | {{dts|1998|4|1}} |[[Troy, New York|Troy]] {{coord|42.7399|-73.681803|name=Kate Mullany House|type:landmark}} |{{RHPcounty|Rensselaer}} |Home of Kate Mullany, early female labor organizer andfounder of [[Collar Laundry Union]] |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMON|*}} | [[African Burial Ground National Monument|African Burial Ground]]

''African Burial Ground National Monument'' | [[Image:African Burial Ground.jpg|100px]] | Apr 19, 1993 | [[Manhattan]] {{coord|40.714558|-74.004384|name=African Burial Ground|type:landmark}} | [[List of Registered Historic Places in New York County, New York|New York]] | Dedicated as National Monument on October 5, 2007; burial site in Lower [[Manhattan]] of over 400 Africans from the 17th and 18th centuries |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMON|*}} | [[Governors Island]]

''Governors Island National Monument'' | | Feb 4, 1985 | [[Manhattan]] | [[List of Registered Historic Places in New York County, New York|New York]] | Island in NY Harbor which served various branches of the US Military from 1783 until the late 1990s; future uses are still being decided |- ! {{NRHPlegend|NMEM|*}} | [[Hamilton Grange National Memorial]] | [[Image:Hamilton-Grange.jpg|100px]] | Dec 19, 1960 | [[Manhattan]] | [[List of Registered Historic Places in New York County, New York|New York]] | Home of [[Alexander Hamilton]]: military officer, lawyer, member of the [[United States Constitutional Convention]], American statesman, first [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]], and [[Founding Father]]; [[facade]] is oldest surviving structure in Manhattan |- |} ==Former NPS areas== There are some former designations in New York. page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Hereford and Worcester

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:River Wye at Symond's Yat Rock, Herefordshire taken 1963 - geograph.org.uk - 784038.jpg|thumb|Upper Wye Gorge and River Wye SSSIs at Symonds Yat Rock, Herefordshire.]] {{GeoGroup}} [[File:The northern Malvern Hills and the jubilee memorials - geograph.org.uk - 909168.jpg|thumb|The Malvern Hills, an SSSI on the boundary of Worcestershire and Herefordshire]] This is a '''list of the [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) in [[Hereford and Worcester]]''', England, United Kingdom. In England the body responsible for designating SSSIs is [[Natural England]], which chooses a site because of its [[fauna]], [[plant|flora]], geological or physiographical features.<ref>{{cite web|title=Notification of SSSIs |work=English Nature |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/special/sssi/notification.cfm |accessdate=6 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515062100/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/special/sssi/notification.cfm |archivedate=15 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> Hereford and Worcester was a county from 1974 to 1998, and it was designated an [[Area of Search]] by Natural England. Since 1998 Hereford and Worcester have been separate counties for local government purposes, but Natural England did not revise its list of counties to take account of the change until around 2014, and this Wikipedia list is still based on the pre-1998 counties. {{As of|2012}}, there are 189 sites designated in this Area of Search.<ref>{{cite web|title=SSSIs in Hereford and Worcester|work=English Nature|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/special/sssi/searchresults.cfm?sssi_name=&frmcounty=1020|accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> There are 27 sites with a purely geological interest, and 154 listed for biological interest. A further 8 sites are designated for both reasons.
Natural England took over the role of designating and managing SSSIs from [[English Nature]] in October 2006 when it was formed from the amalgamation of English Nature, parts of the [[Countryside Agency]] and the [[Rural Development Service]]. Natural England, like its predecessor, uses the [[Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England|1974–1996 county system]]<ref>{{cite web|title=County search of SSSIs |work=English Nature |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/sssi/search.cfm |accessdate=5 August 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819192309/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/sssi/search.cfm |archivedate=19 August 2010 |df= }}</ref> and as such the same approach is followed here. The data in the table is taken from Natural England in the form of citation sheets for each SSSI, and the County Background Datasheet for Hereford and Worcester.<ref name="data">[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/sssi/reportAction.cfm?Report=sdrt07&Category=CF&Reference=1020 Natural England County Background datasheet for Hereford and Worcester SSSIs] Accessed 14 November 2012</ref>
For other counties, see [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]].

==Notes== :{{note label|Area|A|A}}Data rounded to one decimal place. :{{note label|Grid reference|B|B}}Grid reference is based on the [[British national grid reference system]], also known as [[OSGB36]], and is the system used by the [[Ordnance Survey]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Guide to National Grid | work=Ordnance Survey | url=http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/getamap/help.html#gridref | accessdate=3 March 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027134518/http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/getamap/help.html#gridref | archivedate=27 October 2007 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> :{{note label|Map|C|C}}Link to maps using the ''Nature on the Map'' service provided by ''Natural England''.

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Kent

revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Kent|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:River Beult - geograph.org.uk - 1231494.jpg|thumb|350px|The [[River Beult]] north-east of [[Paddock Wood]]|alt=River Beult]] [[Kent]] is a county in the south-eastern corner of England. It is bounded to the north by [[Greater London]] and the [[Thames Estuary]], to the west by [[Sussex]] and [[Surrey]], and to the south and east by the [[English channel]] and the [[North Sea]]. The county town is [[Maidstone]].{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Kent-county-England|title=Kent|publisher=Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate=15 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180422234912/https://www.britannica.com/place/Kent-county-England|archivedate=22 April 2018|df=}} It is governed by [[Kent County Council]], with twelve [[Districts of England|district councils]], [[Ashford Borough Council|Ashford]], [[Canterbury City Council|Canterbury]], [[Dartford Borough Council|Dartford]], [[Dover District Council|Dover]], [[Folkestone & Hythe District|Folkestone and Hythe]], [[Gravesham Borough Council|Gravesham]], [[Maidstone Borough Council|Maidstone]], [[Thanet District Council|Thanet]], [[Tonbridge and Malling Borough Council|Tonbridge and Malling]] and [[Tunbridge Wells Borough Council|Tunbridge Wells]]. [[Medway Council|Medway]] is a separate [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authority]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kent.gov.uk/about-the-council/how-the-council-works/district-councils|title=District councils|publisher=Kent County Council|accessdate=15 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027135727/http://www.kent.gov.uk/about-the-council/how-the-council-works/district-councils|archivedate=27 October 2017|df=}}{{cite web | title = Council and democracy | publisher=Kent County Council | url = http://www.kent.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/ | accessdate =19 April 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070206185542/http://www.kent.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/ |archivedate = 6 February 2007}} The chalk hills of the [[North Downs]] run from east to west through the county, with the wooded [[Weald]] to the south. The coastline is alternately flat and cliff-lined. In England, [[Site of Special Scientific Interest|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) are designated by [[Natural England]], which is responsible for protecting England's natural environment. Designation as an SSSI gives legal protection to the most important wildlife and geological sites.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation|publisher=Natural England|title=Sites of Special Scientific Interest: Designation|accessdate=19 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306231551/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=}} As of May 2018, there are 98 sites designated in Kent.{{cite web|title=Designated Sites View: Kent|publisher=Natural England|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=24&responsiblePerson=&DesignationType=SSSI|accessdate=23 May 2018}} There are 21 sites which have been designated for their geological interest, 67 for their biological interest, and 10 for both reasons. Sixteen sites are [[Special Areas of Conservation]], eight are [[Special Protection Area]]s, twenty-three are [[Nature Conservation Review]] sites, thirty-three are [[Geological Conservation Review]] sites, eleven are [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]]s, nine are [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]] internationally important wetland sites, eleven are [[Local Nature Reserve]]s, thirteen are in [[Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty]], one is on the [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]] and two contain [[Scheduled Monument]]s. Seventeen sites are managed by the [[Kent Wildlife Trust]], four by the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] and seven by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]. ==Key== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Interest=== *'''B''' = site of biological interest *'''G''' = site of geological interest ===Public access=== *'''FP''' = access to footpaths through the site only *'''NO''' = no public access to site *'''PP''' = public access to part of site *'''YES''' = public access to all or most of the site {{col-2}} ===Other classifications=== *'''AONB''' = [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''KWT''' = [[Kent Wildlife Trust]] *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review|Geological Conservation Review site]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local Nature Reserve]] *'''NCR''' = [[Nature Conservation Review|Nature Conservation Review site]] *'''NNR''' = [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]] *'''NT''' = [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] *'''Plant''' = [[Plantlife]], a wild plant conservation charity *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]], an internationally important wetland site *'''RHPG''' = [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]] *'''RSPB''' = [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] *'''SAC''' = [[Special Area of Conservation]] *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]] {{col-end}} {{kml}} ==Sites== {{Compact ToC|side=yes|j=|x=|z=}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" | Area{{efn|name=details|The area and grid reference are taken from the "Details" page for each site on the Natural England database.}} ! scope="col" | Public access ! scope="col" | Location{{efn|name=details}} ! scope="col" | Other classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are provided by Natural England on the ''Magic Map'' website.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Citation{{efn|Citations are provided for each site by Natural England.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|A}}[[Alex Farm Pastures]] | [[File:Alex Farm Pastures 1.jpg|100px|alt=Alex Farm Pastures]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 4.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006780&SiteName=Alex%20Farm%20Pastures&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Alex Farm Pastures|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180216150204/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006780&SiteName=Alex%20Farm%20Pastures&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=16 February 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=2 February 2018|df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord| 51.097|0.806|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alex Farm Pastures}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 966 368}} | |{{Nature on the map|1006780}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006780.pdf Citation] |This site has unimproved neutral grassland, which is a nationally rare habitat. Some of it has been lost to scrub, but in other areas it is maintained by rabbit grazing. There are several uncommon butterflies, including the nationally scarce [[pearl-bordered fritillary]] and [[small pearl-bordered fritillary]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006780.pdf|title=Alex Farm Pastures citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=25 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075930/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006780.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Alkham, Lydden and Swingfield Woods]] | [[File:Coppiced woodland with bluebells - geograph.org.uk - 426972.jpg|100px|alt=Alkham, Lydden and Swingfield Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 228.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001567&SiteName=alkham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Alkham, Lydden and Swingfield Woods |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 30 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180131031140/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001567&SiteName=alkham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 31 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Dover]]
{{coord|51.148|1.23 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alkham, Lydden and Swingfield Woods}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 260 437}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]Ratcliffe, p. 46 |{{Nature on the map|1001567}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001567.pdf Citation] |This site is composed of several steeply sloping woods on chalk soil, together with an area of chalk grassland. The [[groundcover|ground flora]] is diverse, including some unusual plants such as [[lady orchid]] in the woods and [[burnt orchid]] in the meadow.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001567.pdf|title= Alkham, Lydden and Swingfield Woods citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 30 January 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180216150204/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001567.pdf|archivedate= 16 February 2018|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Allington Quarry]] | [[File:Allington Quarry 1.jpg|100px|alt=Allington Quarry]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002844&SiteName=Allington%20Quarry&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Allington Quarry|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180220150741/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002844&SiteName=Allington%20Quarry&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea|archive-date=20 February 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=20 February 2018|df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Maidstone]]
{{coord| 51.29|0.498|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Allington Quarry }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 743 575}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1729 |title= Allington Quarry (Quaternary of South-East England)|series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112160028/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1729 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1002844}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002844.pdf Citation] |This [[Pleistocene]] site has an extensive section through gulls (cracks in the rock) which are filled with [[loess]]. These were probably produced by seasonal freezing and thawing during the last ice age.{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002844.pdf |title=Allington Quarry citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 April 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180524183710/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002844.pdf |archivedate=24 May 2018 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Aylesford Pit]] | [[File:Aylesford Pit 4.jpg|100px|alt=Aylesford Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003079&SiteName=Aylesford%20Pit&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Aylesford Pit|series=Site of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180220151655/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003079&SiteName=Aylesford%20Pit&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=20 February 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=2 February 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Aylesford]]
{{coord| 51.308|0.481|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Aylesford Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 730 595}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=991 |title=Aylesford (Quaternary of South-East England) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=11 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042712/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=991 |archivedate=12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003079}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003079.pdf Citation] |This [[Pleistocene]] site in the [[Terrace (geology)|terrace]] of the [[River Medway]] has yielded many mammalian bones and [[paleolithic]] artefacts, but its geographical isolation from the main [[Thames]] sequence makes precise correlation of Aylesford rocks with those laid down at the same time in Thames sites uncertain.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003079.pdf|title=Aylesford Pit citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=23 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180524183710/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003079.pdf|archivedate=24 May 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|B}}[[Baker's Hole]] | [[File:Bakers Hole 2.jpg|100px|alt=Bakers Hole]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 6.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001611&SiteName=baker&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Baker's Hole |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 14 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180216150204/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001611&SiteName=baker&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 16 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Swanscombe]]
{{coord| 51.444|0.317|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Baker's Hole }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 611 742}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=637 |title= Northfleet (Ebbsfleet valley): Baker's Hole Complex (Quaternary of the Thames) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042415/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=637 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1001611}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001611.pdf Citation] |This internationally renowned site has yielded the largest number of stone tools and flakes in Britain dating to the [[Middle Paleolithic|Early Middle Paleolithic]] (325,000 to 180,000 year ago). Most of them were produced by [[Neanderthals]] using the [[Levallois technique]].Pettit and White, p. 263{{cite journal|first=Scott|last=Beccy|title=The investigation of Baker's Hole, Northfleet, Kent, 1909–1914; the impact of collection history upon the interpretation of archaeological data|url=https://britishmuseum.academia.edu/BeccyScott/Papers/255039/The_investigation_of_Bakers_Hole_Northfleet_Kent_1909-1914_the_impact_of_collection_history_upon_the_interpretation_of_archaeological_data|journal=Proceedings of the Geologists' Association|volume=121|issue=1|year=2010|pages=77–79|publisher=Elsevier|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425082226/http://britishmuseum.academia.edu/BeccyScott/Papers/255039/The_investigation_of_Bakers_Hole_Northfleet_Kent_1909-1914_the_impact_of_collection_history_upon_the_interpretation_of_archaeological_data|archivedate=25 April 2012|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bourne Alder Carr]] | [[File:Metal bridge over River Bourne - geograph.org.uk - 1292939.jpg|100px|alt=Bourne Alder Carr]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 13.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001723&SiteName=bourne&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Bourne Alder Carr |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 30 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180131023943/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001723&SiteName=bourne&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 31 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Sevenoaks]]
{{coord|51.271|0.301 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bourne Alder Carr}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 606 549}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001723}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001723.pdf Citation] |The [[River Bourne, Kent|River Bourne]] runs through a shallow valley, and frequent flushing of the woodland on the banks with water rich in nutrients creates a rich [[groundcover|ground flora]]. There is also an area of swamp around a fish pond.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001723.pdf|title=Bourne Alder Carr citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075948/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001723.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Brookland Wood]] | [[File:In Brooklands Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1744148.jpg|100px|alt=Brookland Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 10.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001705&SiteName=brookland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Brookland Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 30 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180131151122/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001705&SiteName=brookland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 31 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Tunbridge Wells]]
{{coord|51.124|0.371 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Brookland Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 660 387}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001705}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001705.pdf Citation] |This site has diverse types of woodland and [[groundcover|ground flora]]. [[Alder]] is dominant in wet areas and [[Corylus avellana|hazel]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[field maple]] in drier ones. Small streams have a variety of mosses and [[liverwort]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001705.pdf|title= Brookland Woodcitation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 30 January 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080020/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001705.pdf|archivedate= 2 January 2018|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|C}}[[Charing Beech Hangers]] | [[File:Pilgrim's Way - geograph.org.uk - 1193495.jpg|100px|alt=Charing Beech Hangers]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|52.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001734&SiteName=charing&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Charing Beech Hangers |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 30 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180131081240/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001734&SiteName=charing&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 31 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord|51.201|0.831 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Charing Beech Hangers}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 979 484}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001734}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001734.pdf Citation] |This steeply sloping site has mature [[beech]] and [[pedunculate oak|oak]], and the [[groundcover|ground flora]] is varied with some uncommon species. Invertebrates include the rare slug ''[[Limax tenellus]]'' and several scarce moths.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001734.pdf|title=Charing Beech Hangers citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075914/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001734.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Chattenden Woods and Lodge Hill]] | [[File:Great Chattenden Wood - geograph.org.uk - 641989.jpg|100px|alt=Great Chattenden Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 351.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000764&SiteName=lodge&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Chattenden Woods and Lodge Hill |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 30 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180131152629/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000764&SiteName=lodge&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 31 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]]
{{coord| 51.432|0.525|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Chattenden Woods and Lodge Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 756 734}} | |{{Nature on the map|2000764}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000764.pdf Citation] |This site has diverse habitats, including ancient semi-natural woodland, grassland and scrub. There are nationally important numbers of [[Luscinia megarhynchos|nightingales]] in the woods and scrub during the breeding season, and invertebrates include nationally scarce moths.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000764.pdf|title=Chattenden Woods and Lodge Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075856/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000764.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Chequer's Wood and Old Park]] | [[File:Pond on the outskirts of Canterbury - geograph.org.uk - 467218.jpg|100px|alt=Chequer's Wood and Old Park]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 106.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003485&SiteName=chequer%27s&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Chequer's Wood and Old Park |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 31 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180201075304/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003485&SiteName=chequer's&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 1 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Canterbury]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TR 173 586}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=992 |title= Fordwich Pit (Quaternary of South-East England) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042534/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=992 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003485}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003485.pdf Citation] |This site includes Fordwich Pit, which has yielded a large collection of early [[Acheulian]] [[handaxe]]s, between 550,000 and 300,000 old. Habitats include [[alder]] wood in a valley bottom, acidic grassland on dry sandy soil, [[pedunculate oak|oak]] and [[birch]] woodland, scrub and a pond.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003485.pdf|title=Chequer's Wood and Old Park citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=31 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080019/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003485.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}}Pettit and White, p. 152 |- ! scope="row"|[[Church Woods, Blean]] | [[File:Blean Woods Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 534476.jpg|100px|alt=Church Woods, Blean]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 526.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004055&SiteName=church&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Church Woods, Blean|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=31 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201075538/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004055&SiteName=church&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archivedate=1 February 2018|df=}} | align="center"|YES | [[Canterbury]]
{{coord|51.301|1.015 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Church Woods, Blean }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 103 601}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 45 [[National Nature Reserve|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006017&SiteName=blean&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Blean Woods | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 12 January 2018}} [[RSPB]],{{cite web|url= https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/reserves-a-z/blean-woods |title= Blean Woods |publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds|accessdate= 12 January 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0013697&SiteName=blean&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Blean Complex | series= Special Area of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 12 January 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1004055}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004055.pdf Citation] |This broadleaved [[coppice with standards]] wood has a diverse range of trees, a rich [[groundcover|ground flora]], a wide variety of birds and many uncommon invertebrates, including the nationally rare [[heath fritillary]] butterfly.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004055.pdf|title=Church Woods, Blean citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=31 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080046/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004055.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- !
