{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 698 683}} |[[AONB]],{{cite web|url=http://www.kentdowns.org.uk/40-places/cobham-wood|title=Cobham Wood|publisher=Kent Downs|accessdate=14 January 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170530152104/http://www.kentdowns.org.uk/40-places/cobham-wood|archivedate=30 May 2017|df=dmy-all}} [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]]{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/cobham-wood-and-mausoleum|title=Cobham Wood and Mausoleum|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=14 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115185943/https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/cobham-wood-and-mausoleum|archivedate=15 January 2018|df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003501}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003501.pdf Citation] |These woods are partly on acidic [[Thanet Sands]] and partly on chalk soils. There is also an area of arable land which has some uncommon plants, including the very rare and protected [[Althaea hirsuta|rough marsh-mallow]], which has been recorded on the site since 1792.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003501.pdf|title= Cobham Woods citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 14 January 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075919/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003501.pdf|archivedate= 2 January 2018|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Combwell Wood]] | [[File:Rogers Rough Road - geograph.org.uk - 1157698.jpg|100px|alt=Combwell Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 110.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003507&SiteName=combwell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Combwell Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 1 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180202020835/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003507&SiteName=combwell&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 2 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|FP | [[Cranbrook, Kent|Cranbrook]]
{{coord|51.081|0.434 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Combwell Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 706 341}} |[[AONB]]{{cite web|url=http://www.woodlands.co.uk/admin/files/download.php?id=111|title=Combwell Wood Management Plan|date=October 2010|publisher=Forestry Commission|accessdate= 1 February 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003507}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003507.pdf Citation] |Much of this ancient wood has traditionally been [[coppice]]d, but there has probably been undisturbed woodland on steep slopes, and uncommon [[bryophyte]]s here are thought to be survivors from the [[Atlantic (period)|Atlantic warm period]] around 5,000 years ago. There are also several nationally scarce [[water beetle]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003507.pdf|title=Combwell Wood citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075947/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003507.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cowden Meadow]] | [[File:Cowden Meadow 1.jpg|100px|alt=owden Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003525&SiteName=cowden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Cowden Meadow |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 12 March 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180312204756/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003525&SiteName=cowden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 12 March 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|FP | [[Edenbridge, Kent|Edenbridge]]
{{coord|51.153|0.115 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cowden Meadow}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 480 414}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003525}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003525.pdf Citation] |This site has flora which are found on grassland sites which have not been cultivated for many years, such as [[Briza media|quaking grass]], [[oxeye daisy]] and [[pepper saxifrage]]. Wetter areas are dominated by [[Juncus inflexus|hard rush]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003525.pdf|title=Cowden Meadow citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075914/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003525.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cowden Pound Pastures]] | [[File:Cowden Pound Pastures 1.jpg|100px|alt=Cowden Pound Pastures]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1007128&SiteName=cowden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Cowden Pound Pastures |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 12 March 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180313031412/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1007128&SiteName=cowden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 13 March 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Edenbridge, Kent|Edenbridge]]
{{coord|51.169|0.086 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Cowden Pound Pastures}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 459 432}} |[[Kent Wildlife Trust|KWT]]{{cite web |url= http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/cowden-pound-pastures |title= Cowden Pound Pastures |publisher= Kent Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 15 January 2018 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180103072938/http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/cowden-pound-pastures |archivedate= 3 January 2018 |df= dmy-all }} |{{Nature on the map|1007128}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1007128.pdf Citation] |This is unimproved neutral grassland, which is a nationally rare habitat, and it is grazed to prevent scrub invading the pasture. Grasses include [[Cynosurus cristatus|crested dog's tail]] and [[common knapweed]], and an area of wet grassland by a stream has [[Juncus articulatus|jointed rush]] and [[water mint]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1007128.pdf|title=Cowden Pound Pastures citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080017/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1007128.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|D}}[[Dalham Farm]] | [[File:Dalham Farm 4.jpg|100px|alt=Dalham Farm]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 8.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003835&SiteName=dalham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Dalham Farm |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=14 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115124730/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003835&SiteName=dalham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=15 January 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]]
{{coord|51.449|0.557 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Dalham Farm}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 778 753}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1282 |title= High Halstow (Mass movement) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112160047/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1282 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003835}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003835.pdf Citation] |The farm shows [[Mass wasting|mass movement]] of rock and soil on a shallow 8% slope of [[London Clay]], which is seen in ridges across the site. It may be the lowest angled slope failure in Britain, and is important in demonstrating slope degradation where there is no coastal erosion.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003835.pdf|title=Dalham Farm citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=14 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102150158/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003835.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Darenth Wood]] | [[File:Darenth Wood Road in Darenth Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1245801.jpg|100px|alt=Darenth Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 122.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003548&SiteName=darenth&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Darenth Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 15 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180202022347/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003548&SiteName=DARENTH&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 2 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Dartford]]
{{coord|51.426|0.267 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Darenth Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 577 721}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003548}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003548.pdf Citation] |This ancient semi-natural wood has many rare invertebrates, including thirty-two which are nationally scarce and two which are nationally rare: these are beetles which live in dead and dying oak timber, ''[[Grilis pannonicus]]'' and ''[[Platypus cylindricus]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003548.pdf|title=Darenth Wood citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075943/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003548.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs]] | [[File:Langdon Hole near Dover - geograph.org.uk - 1520855.jpg|100px|alt=Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 207.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003577&SiteName=dover&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 1 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180216150204/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003577&SiteName=dover&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 16 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Dover]]
{{coord|51.146|1.371 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 359 439}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=213 |title= Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs (Cenomanian, Turonian, Senonian, Maastrichtian) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112160044/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=213 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/the-white-cliffs-of-dover?PlaceMapClick=367|title=The White Cliffs of Dover|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=15 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116135102/https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/the-white-cliffs-of-dover?PlaceMapClick=367|archivedate=16 January 2018|df=}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0030330&SiteName=dover&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs | series= Special Area of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 15 January 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003577}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003577.pdf Citation] |The cliffs expose fossiliferous rocks dating to 99 and 86 million years ago, during the [[Late Cretaceous]], which are historically important as many geological principles were tested there. The cliffs have many breeding sea birds, and there are diverse algae on the foreshore.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003577.pdf|title=Dover to Kingsdown Cliffs citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=1 February 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080017/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003577.pdf|archive-date=2 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Down Bank]] | [[File:Down Wood and the route of the Stour Valley Walk - geograph.org.uk - 785957.jpg|100px|alt=Down Bank]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005749&SiteName=down%20bank&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Designated Sites View: Down Bank|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 2 February 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180203065700/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005749&SiteName=down%20bank&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archivedate= 3 February 2018|df= }} | align="center"|FP | [[Canterbury]]
{{coord|51.23|0.982 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Down Bank}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 083 521}} | |{{Nature on the map|1005749}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005749.pdf Citation] |This sloping chalk meadow has the nationally endangered [[black-veined moth]] and twenty-eight species of butterfly, including the nationally scarce [[Hamearis lucina|Duke of Burgundy]]. Grassland flora include two nationally scarce species, [[small bedstraw]] and [[man orchid]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005749.pdf|title=Down Bank citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=2 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075912/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005749.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Dryhill Nature Reserve|Dryhill]] | [[File:Ragstone outcrop, Dryhill Nature Reserve, Kent - geograph.org.uk - 168246.jpg|100px|alt=Dryhill]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|11.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000064&SiteName=dryhill&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Dryhill |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 2 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180203064252/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000064&SiteName=dryhill&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 3 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Sevenoaks]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TR 176 409}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003746}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003746.pdf Citation] |This unimproved grassland is dominated by [[Festuca ovina|sheep's fescue]], [[upright brome]] and [[tor-grass]], and it is grazed by sheep and cattle. Notable invertebrates are the rare [[adonis blue]] butterfly and two solitary wasps, ''[[Crossocerus cetratus]]'' and ''[[Crossocerus styrius]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003746.pdf|title=Great Shuttlesfield Down citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=2 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080022/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003746.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Greatness Brickworks]] | [[File:Greatness Brickworks 2.jpg|100px|alt=Greatness Brickworks]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 7.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003761&SiteName=greatness&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Greatness Brickworks |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 12 March 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180313092155/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003761&SiteName=greatness&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 13 March 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Sevenoaks]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 535 577}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=939 |title=Sevenoaks (Aptian-Albian) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=11 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042539/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=939 |archivedate=12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003761}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003761.pdf Citation] |This [[Cretaceous]] site is highly fossiliferous, with many [[ammonite]]s. It is described by [[Natural England]] as "of vital importance in [[biostratigraphic]] research on the [[Gault]] of the [[Weald]]".{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003761.pdf|title=Greatness Brickworks citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075932/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003761.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|H}}[[Halling to Trottiscliffe Escarpment]] | [[File:Footpath junction on Hanginghill Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1160542.jpg|100px|alt=Halling to Trottiscliffe Escarpment]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 600.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003779&SiteName=HALLING&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Halling to Trottiscliffe Escarpment |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 7 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180207182920/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003779&SiteName=HALLING&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 7 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 675 640}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 46, 118 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0030225&SiteName=north%20downs&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: North Downs Woodlands | series= Special Area of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 16 January 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003779}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003779.pdf Citation] |This site on the [[North Downs]] has grassland and [[beech]] woodland on chalk soil. It is [[entomologically]] important, with uncommon insects such as the bug ''[[Cacopsylla|Psylla viburni]]'', and it is the only known location in Britain for the moth ''[[Hypercallia citrinalis]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003779.pdf|title=Halling to Trottiscliffe Escarpment citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=7 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075949/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003779.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ham Street Woods]] | [[File:Ham Street Woods - Gill Farm Track - geograph.org.uk - 21435.jpg|100px|alt=Ham Street Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 175.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001531&SiteName=ham%20street&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ham Street Woods | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 7 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord|51.073|0.866 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ham Street Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 009 343}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 45–46 [[National Nature Reserve|NNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006068&SiteName=ham%20str&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ham Street Woods | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 16 January 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001531}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001531.pdf Citation] |This semi-natural wood is more than 400 years old, and it has rich and diverse invertebrates, including 12 rare or scarce dead wood species, such as the nationally rare beetle, ''[[Tomoxia bucephala|Tomoxia biguttata]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001531.pdf|title=Ham Street Woods citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=7 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075943/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001531.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hart Hill, Kent|Hart Hill]] | [[File:Hart Hill 1.jpg|100px|alt=Hart Hill]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000774&SiteName=hart%20hill&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Hart Hill |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 17 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180218210207/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000774&SiteName=hart%20hill&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 18 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord|51.222|0.780 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Hart Hill}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 942 506}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1481 |title= Hart Hill, (Neogene) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042412/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1481 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1000774}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000774.pdf Citation] |This site is controversial as it exposes the [[Lenham Beds]], the date of which have been disputed, but they are now thought to be [[Pliocene]] on the basis of their marine [[bivalve]]s and [[gastropod]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000774.pdf|title=Hart Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075919/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000774.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hatch Park]] | [[File:Deer Park - geograph.org.uk - 400493.jpg|100px|alt=Hatch Park]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 71.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003805&SiteName=hatch&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hatch Park | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 7 February 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord|51.129|0.946 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Hatch Park }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TR 062 408}} |[[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England|RHPG]]{{cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1001291|title=Hatch Park|publisher=Historic England|accessdate=7 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208064208/https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1001291|archivedate=8 February 2018|df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003805}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003805.pdf Citation] |This site has species-rich acidic grassland which is the remnant of a larger deer park, and is still managed by a herd of deer. There are also ancient pollard woods which are the richest for [[epiphytic]] lichens in the county. Several ponds have adjacent areas of marsh.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003805.pdf|title=Hatch Park citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=7 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075923/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003805.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[High Rocks]] | [[File:High Rocks on top 4117.JPG|100px|alt=High Rocks]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 3.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002928&SiteName=high%20rocks&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: High Rocks | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 8 February 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Tunbridge Wells]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 559 383}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=788|title= High Rocks (Quaternary of South-East England)|series= Geological Conservation Review|publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 11 January 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042418/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=788|archivedate= 12 January 2018|df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1002928}}{{efn|name=es}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002928.pdf Citation] |This [[Pleistocene]] site is described by [[Natural England]] as "a key geomorphological site for sandstone weathering features developed on the highest cliffs in the [[Weald]]". {{gbmappingsmall|TQ 952 425}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003885}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003885.pdf Citation] |This [[pedunculate oak|oak]] and [[hornbeam]] wood is outstanding for its insects, especially butterflies and moths, with two which are nationally rare, the [[Hemaris fuciformis|broad-bordered beehawk]] and [[black-veined moth|black-veined]] moths. There are diverse breeding birds.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003885.pdf|title=Hoad's Wood citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075956/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003885.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Holborough to Burham Marshes]] | [[File:Old Wharf of Wouldham Cement Works - geograph.org.uk - 1060075.jpg|100px|alt=Holborough to Burham Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 149.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003909&SiteName=burham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Holborough to Burham Marshes |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 9 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180210002926/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003909&SiteName=burham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 10 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Snodland]]
{{coord|51.328|0.456 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Holborough to Burham Marshes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 712 616}} |[[Kent Wildlife Trust|KWT]]{{cite web |url= http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/holborough-marshes |title= Holborough Marshes |publisher= Kent Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 25 January 2018 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180103073047/http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/holborough-marshes |archivedate= 3 January 2018 |df= dmy-all }} |{{Nature on the map|1003909}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003909.pdf Citation] |This site is in the tidal flood plain of the [[River Medway]]. It has diverse habitats, with reedbeds, fen, grassland, woodland, scrub and a flooded gravel pit, which attracts wintering wildfowl. There are five rare invertebrates, including three bee species.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003909.pdf|title= Holborough to Burham Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 9 February 2018|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075929/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003909.pdf|archivedate= 2 January 2018|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hollingbourne Downs]] | [[File:View over Hollingbourne Downs(SSSI), Kent, UK.jpg|100px|alt=Hollingbourne Downs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 60.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004489&SiteName=holling&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hollingbourne Downs | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 12 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Maidstone]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 849 557}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004489}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004489.pdf Citation] |This [[escarpment]] has unimproved chalk grassland and [[beech]] woodland. The dominant grasses are [[tor-grass]], [[upright brome]] and [[sheep's fescue]], and shrub species on woodland margins include the [[wayfaring-tree]] and [[Clematis vitalba|traveller's-joy]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004489.pdf|title=Hollingbourne Downs citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080025/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004489.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hothfield Common]] | [[File:Hothfield Common - geograph.org.uk - 408938.jpg|100px|alt=Hothfield Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 56.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001480&SiteName=hothf&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hothfield Common | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 12 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]
{{coord| 51.178|0.814|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Hothfield Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 968 458}} |[[Kent Wildlife Trust|KWT]],{{cite web |url= http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/hothfield-heathlands |title= Hothfield Heathlands |publisher= Kent Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 15 January 2018 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180103073424/http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/hothfield-heathlands |archivedate= 3 January 2018 |df= dmy-all }} [[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]]{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008966&SiteName=hothfield&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Hothfield Common|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 15 January 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001480}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001480.pdf Citation] |This site has areas of heath and the best valley bog in the county, both habitats which are uncommon in Kent. Over a thousand insect species have been recorded, several of which are nationally rare, such as the bee ''[[Lasioglossum semilucens]]'' and the cranefly ''[[Tipula holoptera]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001480.pdf|title=Hothfield Common citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080026/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001480.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Houlder and Monarch Hill Pits, Upper Halling]] | [[File:Houlder and Monarch Hill Pits, Upper Halling.jpg|100px|alt=Houlder and Monarch Hill Pits]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002857&SiteName=houlder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Houlder and Monarch Hill Pits, Upper Halling|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409043156/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002857&SiteName=houlder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archivedate=9 April 2018|df=}} | align="center"|NO | [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 690 634}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2036 |title=Upper Halling (Quaternary of South-East England) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=11 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042410/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2036 |archivedate=12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1002857}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002857.pdf Citation] |This site has a sequence of deposits covering the end of the [[last glacial period]], with two sheets of glacial deposits separated by a fossil soil assigned to the late glacial [[interstadial]] around 13,000 years ago. It provides evidence of [[lithostratigraphic]] and [[biostratigraphic]] changes during this period.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002857.pdf|title=Houlder and Monarch Hill Pits, Upper Halling citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080012/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002857.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hubbard's Hill]] | [[File:Greensand Way in Beechmont Bank near timberworks - geograph.org.uk - 1533350.jpg|100px|alt=Hubbard's Hill]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 66.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000062&SiteName=hubbard&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Hubbard's Hill |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 13 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180213195951/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000062&SiteName=hubbard&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 13 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Sevenoaks]]
{{coord|51.247|0.196 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Hubbard's Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 534 520}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=786 |title=Hubbard`s Hill (Quaternary of South-East England) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate=11 January 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042621/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=786 |archivedate=12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|2000062}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000062.pdf Citation] |This [[Quaternary]] site exhibits [[solifluction]] (erosion by freezing and thawing). The main deposits date to the [[Wolstonian]] glaciation around 130,000 years ago, but the latest have [[radiocarbon date]]s of only 12,500 years, during the most recent [[Younger Dryas]] ice age.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000062.pdf|title=Hubbard's Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=13 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075917/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000062.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|I}}[[Ileden and Oxenden Woods]] | [[File:Track through Pitt Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1100338.jpg|100px|alt=Ileden and Oxenden Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 86.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004508&SiteName=ileden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Ileden and Oxenden Woods|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=13 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180214141956/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004508&SiteName=ileden&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archivedate=14 February 2018|df=}} | align="center"|YES | [[Canterbury]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TR 218 524}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004508}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004508.pdf Citation] |These woods have a variety of soil types and diverse habitats. There is a rich bird community and [[groundcover|ground flora]], including two nationally rare orchids, [[narrow-lipped helleborine]] and [[lady orchid]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004508.pdf|title=Ileden and Oxenden Woods citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=13 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102150200/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004508.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|K}}[[Knole Park]] | [[File:Bracken and trees, Knole park - geograph.org.uk - 857585.jpg|100px|alt=Knole Park]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 383.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004530&SiteName=knole&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Knole Park | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 14 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Sevenoaks]]
{{coord| 51.262|0.210|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Knole Park}}

It has the largest [[heronry]] in Britain, with more than 200 pairs, and insects include the scarce [[sloe carpet]] and [[least carpet]] moths.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003887.pdf|title=Northward Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=19 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075922/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003887.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|O}}[[Oaken Wood]] | [[File:Footpath through Oaken Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1222192.jpg|100px|alt=Oaken Wood]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 18.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003120&SiteName=oaken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Oaken Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 20 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180221111757/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003120&SiteName=oaken&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 21 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Maidstone]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 701 548}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=785 |title= Oaken Wood (Quaternary of South-East England) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042648/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=785 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003120}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003120.pdf Citation] |This site provides the best example of a very unusual [[topography]], with cracking and tilting of underlying weaker strata during the [[Pleistocene]] by [[periglacial]] processes producing crests and troughs in the surface rocks.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003120.pdf|title=Oaken Wood citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=20 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102150154/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003120.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Oldbury and Seal Chart]] | [[File:Redhill Wood, Seal Chart - geograph.org.uk - 478475.jpg|100px|alt=Oldbury and Seal Chart]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 212.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000279&SiteName=oldbury&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Oldbury and Seal Chart |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 20 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180221104640/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000279&SiteName=oldbury&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 21 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Sevenoaks]]
{{coord|51.279|0.255 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Oldbury and Seal Chart }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 574 557}} |[[AONB]], [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]]{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/oldbury-hill|title=Oldbury Hill|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=17 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118122454/https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/oldbury-hill|archivedate=18 January 2018|df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000279}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000279.pdf Citation] |More than 250 species of fungi have been recorded in this site, including 10 which are rare or scarce. There are also molluscs which are characteristic of ancient woodland, including the rare snail ''[[Phenacolumax major]]'' and the scarce slug ''[[Limax tenellus]]''.{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000279.pdf |title= Oldbury and Seal Chart citation |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 17 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075934/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000279.pdf |archivedate= 2 January 2018 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[One Tree Hill and Bitchet Common]] | [[File:Stile on Greensand Way - geograph.org.uk - 1321596.jpg|100px|alt=One Tree Hill and Bitchet Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 79.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000317&SiteName=bitchet&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: One Tree Hill and Bitchet Common |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 21 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180221161607/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000317&SiteName=bitchet&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 21 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Sevenoaks]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 567 534}} |[[AONB]],{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000317.pdf|title=One Tree Hill and Bitchet Common citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075932/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000317.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]]{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/one-tree-hill|title=One Tree Hill|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=17 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118122450/https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/one-tree-hill|archivedate=18 January 2018|df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1000317}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000317.pdf Citation] |This site has mixed woodland on the [[Lower Greensand]], some of it of ancient origin. The habitats are varied, including acidic soils on Bitchet Common and damp, [[base-rich]] soils in Martins Wood. There are several rare plants and invertebrates. |- ! scope="row"|[[Orlestone Forest]] | [[File:Church Lane - geograph.org.uk - 1559869.jpg|100px|alt=Orlestone Forest]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|347.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003149&SiteName=orles&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Orlestone Forest |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 21 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180222044056/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003149&SiteName=orles&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 22 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]

Several are only known in Britain on this site.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003149.pdf|title=Orlestone Forest citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=21 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075905/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003149.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Otford to Shoreham Downs]] | [[File:Bridleway signpost at the beginning of the way to Shoreham - geograph.org.uk - 940960.jpg|100px|alt=Otford to Shoreham Downs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 145.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000333&SiteName=otford&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Otford to Shoreham Downs | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 18 January 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Sevenoaks]]
{{coord|51.335|0.199 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Otford to Shoreham Downs }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 533 618}} |[[AONB]], [[Kent Wildlife Trust|KWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/fackenden-down |title=Fackenden Down |publisher=Kent Wildlife Trust |accessdate=18 January 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103073232/http://www.kentwildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/fackenden-down |archivedate=3 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }} |{{Nature on the map|1000333}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000333.pdf Citation] |These downs have woodland, scrub and species-rich chalk grassland, which has been traditionally managed by grazing. A decline in grazing has caused the chalk downland to become overgrown, but it is still very species diverse, with over a hundred plants recorded.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000333.pdf|title=Otford to Shoreham Downs citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=22 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121073101/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000333.pdf|archivedate=21 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Otterpool Quarry]] | [[File:Otterpool Quarry 1.jpg|100px|alt=Otterpool Quarry]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 10.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003173&SiteName=Otterpool%20Quarry&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Otterpool Quarry |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 29 July 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180729204902/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003173&SiteName=Otterpool%20Quarry&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 29 July 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Lympne]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TR 112 364}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=941 |title= Otterpool Manor (Aptian-Albian) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 11 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112042555/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=941 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003173}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003173.pdf Citation] |This quarry exposes rocks dating to the [[Cretaceous]] period, and shows the contact between the [[Lower Greensand Group|Hythe and Sandgate]] beds. {{gbmappingsmall|TR 043 526}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000344}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000344.pdf Citation] |This wood is mainly [[hazel]] and [[hornbeam]] coppice with [[oak]] standards, and diverse shrub and ground layers. There are many breeding birds and invertebrates, including two which are rare, the wasp ''[[Crossocerus distinguendus]]'' and the fly ''[[Stratiomys potamida]]''.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000344.pdf|title=Park Wood, Chilham citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=22 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075958/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000344.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Park Gate Down|Parkgate Down]] | [[File:Park Gate Down 2.JPG|100px|alt=Parkgate Down]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000359&SiteName=parkgate&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Parkgate Down | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 22 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Canterbury]]

There are a variety of orchids including the uncommon [[lady orchid|lady]] and [[musk orchid]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000359.pdf|title=Parkgate Down citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=22 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075909/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000359.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Parsonage Wood]] | [[File:Parsonage Wood 2.jpg|100px|alt=Parsonage Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 9.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000373&SiteName=parsonage&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Parsonage Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 4 February 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180205072243/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000373&SiteName=parsonage&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 5 February 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Cranbrook, Kent|Cranbrook]]

The trees are mainly coppiced, but some of the [[groundcover|ground flora]] are species which are indicative of ancient woods, such as [[butcher's broom]], [[violet helleborine]] and [[pendulous sedge]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000373.pdf|title=Parsonage Wood citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=4 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075902/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000373.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pembury Cutting and Pit]] | [[File:Blackhurst Lane (2) - geograph.org.uk - 1610790.jpg|100px|alt=Pembury Cutting and Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000982&SiteName=pembury&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Pembury Cutting and Pit|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=22 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180223053550/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000982&SiteName=pembury&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archivedate=23 February 2018|df=}} | align="center"|PP | [[Tunbridge Wells]]

The relationship of this exposure to the [[Swanscombe]] sequence and the [[Thames]] Terraces is a controversial issue in Thames [[Pleistocene]] studies.[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003328.pdf Natural England, Wansunt Pit SSSI citation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024053555/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003328.pdf |date=24 October 2012 }} Stone tools have been found of ''[[Homo heidelbergensis]]'', dating from the [[Hoxnian Stage]], an [[interglacial]] period between 424,000 and 374,000 years ago.{{cite book|url=http://pure.rhul.ac.uk/portal/files/4059178/2011JubyCPhD.pdf|last=Juby|first=Caroline|year=2011|title=London before London: Reconstructing a Palaeolithic Landscape|publisher=Royal Holloway, University of London, Department of Geography|page=94|accessdate=7 January 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029194132/http://pure.rhul.ac.uk/portal/files/4059178/2011JubyCPhD.pdf|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wateringbury SSSI|Wateringbury]] | [[File:Wateringbury SSSI.jpg|100px|alt=Wateringbury]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000063&SiteName=watering&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Wateringbury |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 17 March 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180524183710/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000063&SiteName=watering&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 24 May 2018 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Maidstone]]
{{coord|51.255|0.416 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wateringbury}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ 687 534}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2260 |title= Wateringbury (Quaternary of South-East England) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 12 January 2018 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180112160456/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2260 |archivedate= 12 January 2018 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|2000063}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000063.pdf Citation] |This site contains [[tufa]] which displays a complete sequence of [[mollusc]]s, especially terrestrial snails, dating to the early [[Holocene]], and thus gives a full record of the order in which species colonised the area after the end of the last ice age, the [[Younger Dryas]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000063.pdf|title=Wateringbury citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102075934/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000063.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[West Blean and Thornden Woods]] | [[File:Pond off Thornden Wood Rd, Thornden Woods - geograph.org.uk - 1144399.jpg|100px|alt=Thornden Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|781.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003346&SiteName=west+blean&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: West Blean and Thornden Woods | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 26 January 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Herne Bay, Kent|Herne Bay]]

|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 23 January 2018}} [[NATURE CONSERVATION REVIEW|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 47, 118 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1001339}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001339.pdf Citation] |This stretch of chalk escarpment has woodland, unimproved grassland and scrub. Plants include the nationally rare [[meadow clary]] and there are several scarce invertebrates. There are many [[Mesozoic]] fossil fishes in an excellent state of preservation.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001339.pdf|title=Wouldham to Detling Escarpment citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=3 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080023/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001339.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wye and Crundale Downs]] | [[File:Wye Downs NNR 6.jpg|100px|alt=Wye and Crundale Downs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 358.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003763&SiteName=crund&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wye and Crundale Downs | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 23 January 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]]

2016 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1003763}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003763.pdf Citation] |This site has a variety of habitats, including grassland, calacreous fen meadow, scrub, dry woodland on chalk and wet alder woodland. The Devil’s Kneading Trough, found within the site, is an important geological site displaying [[periglacial]] changes dating to the [[Last glacial period|late glacial period]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003763.pdf|title=Wye and Crundale Downs citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=3 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080037/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003763.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{Anchor|Y}}[[Yockletts Bank]] | [[File:Yockletts Bank 3.jpg|100px|alt=Yockletts Bank]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 25.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001371&SiteName=yock&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Yockletts Bank | series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 February 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Canterbury]]

The [[groundcover|ground flora]], dominated by [[Hyacinthoides non-scripta|bluebells]], also contains many orchids.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001371.pdf|title=Yockletts Bank citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=25 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102080010/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001371.pdf|archivedate=2 January 2018|df=}} |} ==See also== *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Kent]] *[[Kent Wildlife Trust]] {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Kent}} == Notes == {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|title=The British Palaeolithic: Human Societies at the Edge of the Pleistocene World|first1=Paul|last1=Pettit|first2=Mark|last2=White|publisher=Routledge|year=2012|location=Abingdon, UK|isbn=978-0-415-67455-3}} *{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review|volume=2 |authorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher= Cambridge University Press|location =Cambridge, UK |year=1977|isbn= 0-521-21403-3 }} {{SSSIs Kent}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Kent| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Kent]]

page.title: List of native New Zealand ferns

revision.text:
This is a '''list of native New Zealand ferns'''. These are the true ferns in the Division [[Pteridophyta]] that are [[Indigenous (ecology)|native]] to [[New Zealand]]. The ferns of [[Cyathea]] and [[Dicksonia]] are tree ferns that can grow quite high, all the other genus groups are that of ground, climbing or perching ferns.
{{Expand list|date=April 2012}}
{{TOC right}}
==[[Aspleniaceae]]==
There are over 700 species in the genus [[Asplenium]], the '''spleenworts'''. Around 20 are native to New Zealand, with ''[[Asplenium aethiopicum|A. aethiopicum]]'' naturalized since 2003. *''[[Asplenium appendiculatum]]'' - Ground spleenwort, Coastal spleenwort *''[[Asplenium bulbiferum]]'' - Hen and Chickens fern, mouku, manamana *''[[Asplenium chathamense]]'' *''[[Asplenium cimmeriorum]]'' *''[[Asplenium flabellifolium]]'' - Butterfly fern, Necklace fern *''[[Asplenium flaccidum]]'' - Hanging spleenwort, raukatauri *''[[Asplenium gracillimum]]'' *''[[Asplenium haurakiense]]'' - Hauraki Gulf spleenwort *''[[Asplenium hookerianum]]'' - Hooker's spleenwort *''[[Asplenium lamprophyllum]]'' *''[[Asplenium lyallii]]'' - Lyall's spleenwort *''[[Asplenium northlandicum]]'' - Northern shore spleenwort *''[[Asplenium oblongifolium]]'' - Shining spleenwort, huruhuruwhenua *''[[Asplenium obtusatum]]'' - Shore spleenwort, paranako, parenako *''[[Asplenium pauperequitum]]'' - Poor Knights spleenwort *''[[Asplenium polyodon]]'' - Sickle spleenwort, petako *''[[Asplenium richardii]]'' - Richard's spleenwort, matua-kaponga *''[[Asplenium scleroprium]]'' (A. aucklandicum) *''[[Asplenium shuttleworthianum]]'' *''[[Asplenium subglandulosum]]'' - Blanket fern *''[[Asplenium trichomanes]]'' - Maidenhair spleenwort
==[[Blechnaceae]]== *''[[Blechnum chambersii]]'' - Lance water fern *''[[Blechnum colensoi]]'' - Waterfall fern, Colenso's hard fern *''[[Blechnum discolor]]'' - Crown fern *''[[Blechnum fluviatile]]'' - Creek fern, kiwikiwi *''[[Blechnum filiforme]]'' - Thread fern *''[[Blechnum fraseri]]'' - Miniature Tree Fern *''[[Blechnum penna-marina]]'' - Alpine Water Fern *''[[Blechnum procerum]]'' - Mountain Kiokio *''[[Blechnum novae-zelandiae]]'' - Palm-Leaf Fern, Kio kio *''[[Doodia media]]'' - Rasp fern
==[[Cyatheaceae]]== *''[[Cyathea colensoi]]'' - Mountain tree fern *''[[Cyathea cunninghamii]]'' - Gully tree fern, Slender tree fern or Ponga *''[[Cyathea dealbata]]'' - Silver tree fern, Silver fern, Kaponga or Ponga *''[[Cyathea kermadecensis]]'' – Kermadec tree fern ([[Kermadec Islands]]) *''[[Cyathea medullaris]]'' – Black tree fern, Mamaku *''[[Cyathea milnei]]'' – Milnes tree fern ([[Kermadec Islands]]) *''[[Cyathea smithii]]'' – Soft tree fern, Katote
==[[Dennstaedtiaceae]]== *''[[Histiopteris incisa]]'' – Water Fern *''[[Hypolepis ambigua]]'' – Pig Fern *''[[Hypolepis millefolium]]'' – Thousand-Leaved Fern * ''[[Leptolepia novae-zelandiae]]'' - Lace Fern *''[[Paesia scaberula]]'' – Ring Fern *''[[Pteridium esculentum]]'' – [[Bracken]]
==[[Dicksoniaceae]]== *''[[Dicksonia squarrosa]]'' – wheki, rough tree fern, *''[[Dicksonia fibrosa]]'' – wheki-ponga *''[[Dicksonia lanata]]'' – tūōkura
==[[Dryopteridaceae]]== *''[[Lastreopsis glabella]]'' *''[[Lastreopsis hispida]]'' – Hairy fern *''[[Polystichum richardii]]'' – Common shield fern *''[[Polystichum vestitum]]'' – Prickly shield fern
==[[Elaphoglossaceae]]== *''[[Rumohra adiantiformis]]'' – climbing shield fern
==[[Gleicheniaceae]]== *''[[Diranopteris linearis]]'' *''[[Gleichenia dicarpa]]'' – Tangle fern, spider fern, swamp umbrella fern *''[[Gleichenia circinnata]]'' – Tangle fern, spider fern, swamp umbrella fern *''[[Gleichenia microphylla]]'' – Carrier tangle, parasol fern, waewaekākā *''[[Sticherus cunninghamii]]'' – Umbrella fern, tapuwae kōtuku, waekura *''[[Sticherus flabellatus]]'' *''[[Sticherus tener]]''
==[[Grammitidaceae]]== *''[[Ctenopteris herterphylla]]'' – Comb fern, Gypsy Fern *''[[Grammitis billardierei]]'' – Common strap fern *''[[Grammitis ciliata]]'' *''[[Grammitis gunnii]]'' *''[[Grammitis magellanica]]'' *''[[Grammitis patagonica]]'' *''[[Grammitis pseudociliata]]'' *''[[Grammitis rawlingsii]]'' *''[[Grammitis ridida]]''
==[[Hymenophyllaceae]]== *''[[Hymenopyllum armstrongii]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum atrovirens]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum bivalve]]'' *''[[Hymenophyllum cupressiforme]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum demissum]]'' – Drooping filmy fern, irirangi, piripiri *''[[Hymenopyllum dilatatum]]'' – Matua, mauku *''[[Hymenopyllum ferrugineum]]'' – Rusty filmy fern *''[[Hymenophyllum flabellatum]]'' – Fan-like filmy fern *''[[Hymenopyllum fleuosum|Hymenophyllum flexuosum]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum lyallii|Hymenophyllum lyallii]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum malingii|Hymenophyllum malingii]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum minimum|Hymenophyllum minimum]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum multifidum|Hymenophyllum multifidum]]'' – Much-divided filmy fern *''[[Hymenophyllum nephrophyllum]] –'' kidney fern, konehu, kopakapa, raurenga *''[[Hymenopyllum peltatum|Hymenophyllum peltatum]]'' – One-sided filmy fern *''[[Hymenopyllum pulcherrimun|Hymenophyllum pulcherrimun]]'' – Tufted filmy fern *''[[Hymenopyllum rarum|Hymenophyllum rarum]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum revoltum|Hymenophyllum revolutum]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum refescens|Hymenophyllum rufescens]]'' *''[[Hymenopyllum sanguinolentum|Hymenophyllum sanguinolentum]]'' – Piripiri *''[[Hymenopyllum scabrum|Hymenophyllum scabrum]]'' – Rough filmy fern *''[[Hymenopyllum villosum|Hymenophyllum villosum]]'' – Hairy filmy fern *''[[Trichomanes colensoi]]'' *''[[Trichomanes elongatum]]'' – Bristle fern *''[[Trichomanes endlicherianum]]'' *''Trichomanes venosum''
==[[Marattiaceae]]== *''[[Ptisana salicina]]'' - King fern, horseshoe fern, para
==[[Osmundaceae]]== *''[[Leptopteris hymenophylloides]]'' – Single crepe fern, heruheru *''[[Leptopteris superba]]'' – Crepe fern, Prince of Wales feathers, heruheru, ngātukākariki, ngutungutu kiwi *''[[Osmeunda regalis]]'' – Royal fern *''[[Todea barbara]]'' – Hard todea
==[[Ophioglossaceae]]== *''[[Botrychium australe]]'' – Parsley fern, patotara *''[[Botrychium biforme]]'' – Fine-leaved parsley fern *''[[Botrychium lunaria]]'' – Moonwort *''[[Ophioglossum coriaceum]]'' – Adder’s tongue *''[[Ophioglossum petiolatum]]'' – Stalked adder tongue
==[[Polypodiaceae]]== *''[[Loxogramme dictyopteris]]'' – Lance fern *''[[Microsorum pustulatum]]'' – Hounds tongue fern, kōwaowao, pāraharaha *''[[Microsorum novae-zealandiae]]'' *''[[Microsorum scandens]]'' – Fragrant fern, mokimoki *''[[Polypodium vulgare]]'' – Common polypody *''[[Pyrrosia eleagnifolia]]'' – Leather-leaf fern
==[[Pteridaceae]]== *''[[Adiantum aethiopicum]]'' – True maidenhair, mākaka *''[[Adiantum capillus-veneris]]'' – European maidenhair, venus-hair fern *''[[Adiantum cunninghamii]]'' – Common maidenhair, Cunningham’s maidenhair *''[[Adiantum diaphanum]]'' – Small maidenhair *''[[Adiantum formosum]]'' – Giant maidenhair, plumed maidenhair *''[[Adiantum fulvum]]'' *''[[Adiantum hispidulum]]'' – Rosy maidenhair *''[[Adiantum Raddianum]]'' *''[[Adiantum viridescens]]'' *''[[Anogramma leptophylla]]'' – Annual fern, Jersey fern *''[[Cheilanthes distans]]'' – Woolly cloak fern, woolly rock fern *''[[Cheilanthes sieberi]]'' – Rock fern *''[[Pellaea calidirupium]]'' *''[[Pellaea falcata]]'' *''[[Pellaea rotundifolia]]'' – Button fern, round-leaved fern, tarawera <!-- *''[[Pellaea viridis]]'' NOT NATIVE - GARDEN ESCAPEE --> *''[[Pteris comans]]'' – Coastal brake, netted brake *''[[Pteris cretica]]'' – Cretan brake <!-- *''[[Pteris dentata]]'' – Toothed brake NOT NATIVE - GARDEN ESCAPEE --> *''[[Pteris macilenta]]'' – Sweet fern *''[[Pteris saxatilis]]'' – Carse *''[[Pteris tremula]]'' – Shaking brake, tender brake, turawera <!-- *''[[Pteris vittata]]'' - Chinese brake NOT NATIVE - GARDEN ESCAPEE --> *''[[Pneumatopteris pennigera]]'' – Gully fern
==[[Schizaeaceae]]== *''[[Lygodium articulatum]]'' – Bushman's mattress, makamaka, mangemange *''[[Schizaea australis]]'' – Southern comb fern *''[[Schizaea dichotoma]]'' – Fan fern *''[[Schizaea fistulosa]]'' – Comb fern
==See also== * [[List of native New Zealand fern allies]] * [[Flora of New Zealand]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Brownsey, P. and Smith-Dodsworth, J (2000) ''New Zealand ferns and allied plants'', Auckland, David Bateman Ltd. * [http://nzflora.landcareresearch.co.nz/ Landcare Research: Ngā Tipu o Aotearoa—New Zealand Plants]
[[Category:Ferns of New Zealand| ]] [[Category:Lists of biota of New Zealand|Native New Zealand ferns]] [[Category:Lists of plants|New Zealand Ferns]] [[Category:Pteridophyta of Oceania|.New Zealand]]
